p: Infrequently seen in children, hepatic involvement may occur in secondary syphilis. Cholestatic hepatitis with congenital syphilis has been described. The frequency of hepatitis then ranges from 1 to 50 %. In addition to nonspecific symptoms such as anorexia and weight loss, a characteristic maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles is seen. Jaundice as well as hepatomegaly and right upper quadrant pain is described. Histological examination of the liver reveals hepatitis with spirochetes demonstrated on silver stain. Treatment of the infection is with penicillin [ 29].
